These stories contain many consistencies and raise serious questions about not only this particular doctor but about the entire detention system‚Äîlargely for-profit‚Äîthat is complicit in the abuses and has long neglected the health, wellbeing, and human rights of immigrants.

Another woman, already deported, apparently went in to see the doctor for a simple condition related to diabetes and ended up having gynecological surgery. Two additional women apparently were shackled to the bed, reported to have had surgical procedures including a hysterectomy.

One woman, who was nearly deported, consulted the doctor simply about her menstrual cycle. She was put under for what she was told would be a simple procedure, only to wake up and find that the doctor had removed part of her reproductive organs without her knowledge or consent.

(12/12) As oceans warm, sea levels rise, tropical storms grow more deadly and wildfires sear our world, we must find immediate ways to slow and reverse #ClimateChange or face these dire consequences of inaction.

(11/12) This bill was inspired by the work of @UCSanDiego @Scripps_Ocean's Dr. Veerabhadran Ramanathan, whose research was published by The New York Times in 2013:
https://www.nytimes.com/2013/01/16/science/earth/burning-fuel-particles-do-more-damage-to-climate-than-thought-study-says.html

(10/12) It would direct agencies to form an action plan to reduce super pollutants, boost standards for global methane emissions, codify methane emission rules for new sources, and regulate emissions if industry efforts don‚Äôt decrease emissions by 40% below 2012 levels.

(9/12) While the president has backpedaled on regulatory rules, I have spent years working to curb these kinds of emissions. What first started as the SUPER Act I authored in 2013, has become the bipartisan Super Pollutants Act I introduced last year.  https://scottpeters.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/reps-peters-gaetz-introduce-bill-to-slow-climate-change-reduce-super

(8/12) This is because methane, a main component in natural gas, is a super pollutant far more potent & harmful than CO2. To take advantage of what natural gas offers, it's vital that commonsense regulations are in place to ensure fugitive natural gas emissions are under control.

(7/12) Natural gas presents itself as a ‚Äúbridge fuel‚Äù that could help us move to a more sustainable future. While natural gas burns cleaner than coal, any climate benefits are wasted if more than 3.2% escapes through fugitive emissions. https://www.ucsusa.org/resources/environmental-impacts-natural-gas

(6/12) It‚Äôs also cheap. According to @EIAgov, in June 2008, natural gas hit a high of $12.41 per thousand cubic feet. In just 4 years, natural gas has declined almost 80% and there is nothing stopping it from going lower. https://www.forbes.com/sites/investopedia/2012/06/13/4-reasons-natural-gas-is-so-cheap/#6a778eebe984

(5/12) Natural gas is everywhere. üá∫üá∏ is the world‚Äôs largest producer of natural gas, having produced some 761.1 billion cubic meters in 2017. We're also the world‚Äôs largest consumer of natural gas, w/ a consumption of 767 billion cubic meters in 2017, too. https://www.statista.com/topics/3172/global-natural-gas-industry/

(4/12) Since coming to office, President Trump has actively worked to dismantle critical supervisory systems, insisting oil & gas companies have their emissions under control. According to this @nytimes piece, however, that is clearly far from the truth.
https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/12/climate/methane-natural-gas-flaring.html

(3/12) Aggressively cutting super pollutants now could avoid 1.5 degrees of warming by the end of the century. Other research demonstrates that curbing super pollutants could reduce sea level rise 18% by 2050.
(2/12) #Methane emissions are responsible for about 25% of the man-made global warming we‚Äôre experiencing today. https://www.edf.org/climate/methane-other-important-greenhouse-gas

(THREAD 1/12) Controlling methane is the single most important step we can take to combat the #ClimateCrisis. Not only is it good for the environment and for public health, but it can create jobs in retrofitting, monitoring, and innovation. https://www.edf.org/how-reducing-methane-emissions-creates-jobs

Output gaps are frequently caused, or at least exacerbated by, too-tight monetary policy. While addressing this policy failure cannot solve all problems with the economy, it can mitigate the problem of otherwise-capable people failing, en masse, to find work.
Cumulatively, we lost at least $4 trillion in income and 45 million person-years of work. We should consider this outcome unacceptable.

The most recent example of a large output gap comes from the 2008-2009 recession, when 8.7 million nonfarm jobs were shed. The output gap then persisted for about a decade; the jobs were not immediately regained, but rather, slowly added back over a period of many years.

Output gaps essentially involve the cyclical unemployment: the work and income lost to the business cycle. To the extent that output gaps are measurable, one could measure them in person-years of work lost, or cumulative GDP lost over time.

What are output gaps?
Output gaps are the difference between actual output (what the economy produces) and potential output (the maximum amount the economy could produce sustainably over the long term with financial stability.)

3/4 We've had an 80% decline in timber harvested out of our federal forests since 1980 and we've had a concomitant increase in acreage destroyed by fire.
2/4 Then, in the 1970s we began imposing environmental laws that have made it all but impossible to carry out that timber. What we've seen over those decades, is increasingly severe forest fires.

1/4 Excess timber comes out of the forest in one of two ways, it's either carried out or it burns out. We used to carry it out, it was called logging. We had healthy forests and we had a thriving economy.
